needle: Figs are one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Prosciutto is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Goat cheese is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

model_response.text:
When talking to corp dev people, the biggest obstacle to a successful deal is the conversation itself, not the size of the company.  It is a trap that's easy to avoid by asking if the company wants to sell right now, and if the answer is no, telling them to focus on growing the company instead.  What if your company's not quite ready to scale?The conversation could be even more difficult to avoid if the questioner would ask if you're looking to sell, and then negotiate from there.  But that's a negotiation.  The first question is a trick in the sense that it's bait.  The idea is that the first conversation should be about how to improve your current business plan, not the value of the company or whether you're looking to be bought.[1] <PAUSE>  If your first conversation is about something else, you can use the information gathered from that conversation to decide if your company is the one to buy.A conversation about your business plan, or about the potential for your business
to grow, would let the acquirers see what you know and what you do
well.  If they seem interested and can explain what they would do with
your business, then the real decision will be based on whether
they'll pay you enough, and not on the question of whether you
want to sell.  That's not how I think people think.  We should
avoid these conversations altogether.  We should just say "no, we're
focusing on growing."  If the buyer doesn't take that, you can
continue to discuss whether you'll do the deal or not, but there
should be no discussion of your business plan.  You've already
made your pitch (even if you've been pretending you haven't) and
you can now say no or yes.[2] <PAUSE>  If you want to start a company, consider doing so.  If you
aren't ready for that, don't do it.  Or consider working at a
small company and getting rich.  If you're in the middle, say no to
the deal.[3] <PAUSE> You can say no to the deal when a company's growth model
doesn't work.[4] <PAUSE>  The founders of the video streaming service Sling TV
got a lot of attention when they announced that they would begin
cutting off support for their small
